project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. *Summary*

There is a "\" symbol in the issue comment link causing it to not work. 

h3. *Environment*
* JIRA 7.12.1

h3. *Steps to Reproduce*
# Set up a new JIRA 7.12.1. 
# Install Service Desk 3.15.1. 
# Create a Service Desk project and a new issue. 
# Comment on the issue. 
# Copy the comment link. 

h3. *Expected Results*

The link to be work as usual: 
{code:none} 
<base-url>/browse/TEST-1?focusedCommentId=10000&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-10000
{code} 

h3. *Actual Results*
There is a backslash ("\") right before the hash ("#"): 
{code:none} 
<base-url>/browse/TEST-1?focusedCommentId=10000&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel\#comment-10000
{code} 
 
h3. *Notes*
* This is not affecting JIRA Core and JIRA Software. 
* It is related to Service Desk component plugin: Atlassian JWT Plugin (jwt-plugin-1.6.0-0005.jar). If this plugin is removed from JIRA_HOME/plugins/installed-plugins directory and restart the JIRA, the issue will go away. However, this could break some other components so it is *not advisable*. 

h3. *Workaround*
Remove the backslash ("\") from the comment will make the link to be working again.
fields.summary: There is a "\" symbol in the issue comment link causing it to not work

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In the Customer notifications the ${request.details}  does not respect the request type configuration and it shows all the details fields of an issue.
Also the hidden fields.

*Scenario 1*
If an approver is also a customer the hidden (private) fields  are displayed in the approval notification.

*Scenario 2*
If you add ${request.details} to any of the customer notifications the full issue details will be added.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure a hidden fields on a request type.
# add the ${request.details}  to any of the customer notifications.

h3. Expected Results
${request.details} should hide the fields that are hidden in the request type.


h3. Actual Results
${request.details} shows all the fields of the issue including the hidden fields

 

h3.Workaround
Remove the ${request.details}  from all the customer notifications.
fields.summary: Customer Notifications : ${request.details} shows hidden fields from the request type.

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 6-Dec-2018|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hello, everyone! After comparing this bug request against the known bug report [JSDSERVER\-5786: Service Desk customer sign up/password reset page does not indicate if the password does not meet the password policy requirements|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-5786] we realized that both are addressing the same scenario and error. We will be closing this request now and will ask you to cast your votes and add any additional feedback so we can have the impact of this issue gathered in one single request.

Best regards,
Amirul
{panel}

h3. Summary
Customer portal reset password does not show any error message when password complexity is not met. Users are prone to confusion because "nothing happens".

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In Service Desk project, add new customer
# Implement basic password complexity policy in JIRA.
# From customer portal, use the password reset link.
# Click on password reset link and attempt to reset the password by entering a simple password that does not meet password complexity. Example:
#* 12345

h3. Expected Results
Jira should display error message stating that password complexity is not met.

h3. Actual Results
Nothing happens. 
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

h3.Workaround
None.

fields.description:
JIRA Version: 7.3.2

Service Desk Version: 3.3.2

We already have our defined Notification Scheme for the Service Desk Project like who should be notified on which transitions of the Issues. After updating to JIRA 7.3.2 we have also set up some Customer Notifications in Project Settings of a Service Desk Project. But it looks like Service Desk agents/ Internal Customers are also getting the emails which are being set from the customer notifications tab on Project level. 

It is not easily traceable when the Notification Scheme is coming into picture and when the Customer Notifications on Project Level are being used to sent the email Notifications.

We also have one Approval Workflow where we would like to have the email sent to other approvers when one approver approves or declines the Issue. Selection of Approvers is being done on the post function of one of the Transition according to the Organization Structure. Even if this is explicitly included in a Notification scheme other approvers does not get any email on the updation of the Issue. Also took help of Notification Helper and it says that other Approver should be notified for a particular transaction ( Approve / Decline). 

Would like to have a suggestion, how to go further with these Email Notifications?

Thanks a lot in advance.

PreetiD
fields.summary: Notification Scheme Notifications and Project Settings - Customer Notifications

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Jira Service Desk keeps information of all the executed automation rules and they are stored in the database. If the automations are heavily used the DB tables can grow very large and later on impact in migration processes.

h3. Suggested Solution

Create a scheduled job that cleans this information from the database. A similar feature was implemented for SLA audit logs with this ticket JSDSERVER-5266.
fields.summary: Provide clean up schedule job for the SD Automation audit logs

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The workload reports page shows list of agents, their assigned issue counts and number of breached and ongoing issues.
To find the breached and ongoing issues we completely calculate everything to do with SLAs leading to slow performance.
The configuration in the attached screenshot took 23 seconds to load.


 !Screen Shot 2018-09-28 at 5.22.07 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Try to load a Workload report

h3. Expected Results
Report loads in a reasonable time

h3. Actual Results
Report take a very long time to load like ~30secs
 

h3.Notes
For all issues that have an assignee, we loop through all SLAs, and get goalSummaryData. 
In getting goal data, we retrieve everything about ongoing goals, including expected breach date that gets active ranges in nested loops. This is already O(n^4). It's possible that there is a worse flow.
fields.summary: Workload report loads very slowly

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Comment links in Service Desk 3.14 are broken and cannot be pulled up in a browser.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an issue and add a comment
 # Click on the permalink icon in a comment box to open the focused comment link in a new window or on the same page.

h3. Expected Results

The comment link opens up just fine and brings you to the focused comment.
h3. Actual Results

For Service Desk projects specifically, the comment link opens up and brings up a 400 error in Chrome and displays a blank page in Firefox.
h3. Notes

This seems to be caused by the following item in the URL link:
{code:java}
com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel\#comment-10000
{code}
If you remove the \ before the # sign, the comment link loads up just fine. Note that this seems to only apply to Service Desk issues starting in 3.14.
h3. Workaround

Remove the \ from the URL before the {{#comment}} section of the URL.
fields.summary: Comment links for Service Desk issues in the internal view do not display in browser

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Summary

On big Jira Service desk instances, having JSD projects with a large number of SLAs, is going to impact the issue reindex performance significantly.
Foreground indexing becomes slow, issue operations like creation, adding a comment or transitions are also impacted as those require indexing.

h3. Environment
 * JIRA 7.5.x or higher, JIRA Service Desk 3.8.x or higher
 * Large instance, more than 1 million issues.
 * Large number of SLAs defined on the instance, more than 100 SLAs.

h3. Expected Results
The re-indexing process takes roughly the same time as for ServiceDesk 3.2.x 

h3. Actual Results
The re-indexing process can take more than 48 hours to finish

h3. Notes
Problem is largely reduced by JSDSERVER-5681 and JSDSERVER-5685 

h3. Technical details
JIRA generates a lot of database queries to populate the index with SLA values. JIRA doesn't use the cache to update the index any more, the database is the source of truth.

The queries are fast but the sheer number of them add up.
 On large instances, the re-indexing process can take more than 48 hours to finish, which doesn't fit in a weekend any more.

Enabling debug logging on the package: *com.querydsl.sql.AbstractSQLQuery* shows many queries going to: *AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC* during an issue comment operation.
 We go to the database as many times as we have SLA's in the scope of the issue:
{noformat}
2018-08-16 09:22:23,527 SdOffThreadEventJobRunner:thread-5 DEBUG <user> 000x000x2 qqq9999 <IP_address> /rest/api/2/issue/PROJECTKEY-1111/comment [c.querydsl.sql.AbstractSQLQuery] select * from (   select "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."ID", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."NAME", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."CUSTOM_FIELD_ID", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."DEFINITION_CHANGE_DATE", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."DEFINITION_CHANGE_MS_EPOCH", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."GOALS_CHANGE_DATE", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."GOALS_CHANGE_MS_EPOCH", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."THRESHOLDS_CONFIG_CHANGE_DATE", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."THRESHOLDS_CHANGE_MS_EPOCH", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."CREATED_DATE" from "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC" "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC" where "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."SERVICE_DESK_ID" = ? and "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."CUSTOM_FIELD_ID" = ? ) where rownum <= ?
2018-08-16 09:22:23,531 SdOffThreadEventJobRunner:thread-5 DEBUG <user> 000x000x2 qqq9999 <IP_address> /rest/api/2/issue/PROJECTKEY-1111/comment [c.querydsl.sql.AbstractSQLQuery] select * from (   select "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."ID", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."NAME", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."CUSTOM_FIELD_ID", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."DEFINITION_CHANGE_DATE", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."DEFINITION_CHANGE_MS_EPOCH", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."GOALS_CHANGE_DATE", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."GOALS_CHANGE_MS_EPOCH", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."THRESHOLDS_CONFIG_CHANGE_DATE", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."THRESHOLDS_CHANGE_MS_EPOCH", "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."CREATED_DATE" from "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC" "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC" where "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."SERVICE_DESK_ID" = ? and "AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC"."CUSTOM_FIELD_ID" = ? ) where rownum <= ?


 ~/ $ grep "PROJECTKEY-1111/comment" atlassian-jira.log|grep AO_54307E_TIMEMETRIC |wc -l
256
~/ $
{noformat}
Taking thread dumps while doing foreground indexing, we can see all the indexing threads are spending extended amount of time doing SLA work.
{code:java}
"IssueIndexer:thread-20" #416026 prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x0000000008c02800 nid=0x151e runnable [0x00007fdd8f46d000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
...
        at com.atlassian.pocketknife.internal.querydsl.DatabaseAccessorImpl.runInTransaction(DatabaseAccessorImpl.java:43)
        at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.customfield.JIRACustomFieldValueStore.getTextValues(JIRACustomFieldValueStore.java:29)
        at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.customfield.SLACFType.getValuesFromDatabase(SLACFType.java:471)
        at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.customfield.SLACFType.loadSLAValue(SLACFType.java:440)
        at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.customfield.SLACFType.lambda$getValueFromIssue$4(SLACFType.java:435)
        at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.customfield.SLACFType$$Lambda$1107/517974037.get(Unknown Source)
{code}
It would be useful if we can tune the amount of times we need to go to the database while working with Service Desk SLAs, as doing database IO quite expensive.
fields.summary: Issue update/create is slow due to SLA indexing takes a long time

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If *agenta* is both an agent and a customer of an SD project (project key BSD)

 And *BSD-2* has a security level whereby agenta is not allowed to view it as an agent (from JIRA) but is allowed to view it as a customer (from SD Portal)

  Then BSD-2 doesn't appear on the *My requests* page of agenta under certain conditions
----
h3. Steps to reproduce
h4. 1 - Setting up User & Group & Application Access
 # Create group agent-a
 # Create user agenta and add him to group agent-a
 # Also give agenta application access to JIRA Service Desk:
 !usergroup.png|thumbnail!

h4. 2 - Setting up Project Roles & Issue Security Scheme
 # Create an Issue Security Scheme this way:
 !security.png|thumbnail!
 ** From JIRA:
 *** agenta can view issues of Level A, but not Admin Level
 *** An admin can view issues of either level
 ** From Customer Portal, agenta should be able to view all issues he reports or is a participant in, regardless of security levels
 # Create an IT Service Desk project and associate it with the above Issue Security Scheme
 # Edit project roles and add agenta to Service Desk Team and Service Desk Customers roles, so that he will be both agent and customer:
 !roles.png|thumbnail!

h4. 3 - Reproducing the issue
 # As admin:
 ** Add agenta as a participant in the sample issue that is created in the project, BSD-1 - this issue has no security level
 ** Raise a new request on behalf of agenta, BSD-2
 ** Edit BSD-2 and set security level to Admin Level
 # Observe these behaviors when *logged in as agenta*:
 ** As an agent, agenta is able to view BSD-1 but not BSD-2 in JIRA, which is expected due to security levels (/)
 ** From Customer Portal, agenta sees 1 in Requests / My requests, which is expected since he's the reporter of BSD-2 (/)
 ** However, *no request shows up* in the list of My requests, which is unexpected since BSD-2 should appear (x)
 !myrequest.png|thumbnail!
 ** Switching to All requests, agenta sees BSD-1, which is expected since he's a participant (/)
 ** Clicking BSD-1 then changing the URL to BSD-2, agenta is able to view BSD-2 (flag)
 !view.png|thumbnail!

----
h3. Workaround
 # As admin, do either of the followings:
 ** Simply add/remove another user to/from another group that has *nothing to do* with the project or issue security scheme
 ** Remove agenta from Service Desk Team role of the project then add him back to the role
 # As agenta, refresh the My requests page, and BSD-2 now shows up:
 !canview.png|thumbnail!
# Since only affected users are customers who are agents at the same time, another workaround is to use Agent view, where they will be able to see these ticket. In this case, agent should be allowed access by appropriate security level.

(!) The issue may happen again intermittently, in different ways. Please refer to the Notes section below for a consistent way to reproduce it.
h3. Notes

The issue can be consistently reproduced this way, after being temporarily worked around by tweaking project roles and/or group memberships:
 # As agenta, log out
 # As admin, remove agenta from jira-servicedesk-users group, so that agenta loses application access
 # As admin, add agenta back to jira-servicedesk-users group, so that agenta regains application access
 # As agenta, log in JIRA, *not Portal*
 # As agenta, perform a search of project BSD in Issue Navigator so that only BSD-1 will be visible to him
 # As agenta, go to Customer Portal and observe that BSD-2 disappears again
 # And so on

(flag) At step 4, if agenta logs in Portal, the issue can't be reproduced whereby BSD-2 will be visible as expected. This seems to indicate that, after agenta logs in JIRA as a *_new_* agent and searches for issues in the project, Lucene is repopulated in a way that it only takes BSD-1 into account. Then when agenta goes to Portal only BSD-1 will be there.

(i) Take note that agenta is still able to view BSD-2 by accessing its Portal URL directly.
----
h3. Findings & Suggestions
 * The *request count* and *request search* are expected to be in sync, but they're not. For some reason, the search result is *incorrect*, and it may have something to do with *security levels*.
 * It's discovered that the request count *does not use the same search* that returns the search result. It performs search with security overridden which bypasses the issue security scheme.

(+) A possible solution is to make the request search use the same search as the request count.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When the summary of a Service Desk issue contains special characters such as the minus character "-", the Knowledge Base search is treating them as Confluence search operators and as a result, relevant articles are missing from the Related Knowledge Base Panel.
h3. Steps to reproduce
 - Link a Confluence instance to a JIRA instance
 - Create a Confluence Space in Confluence
 - Create a page in the Confluence Space with the title "How to order a cellphone for work"
 !Step1.png|thumbnail!
 - Create a Service Desk project in JIRA, and configure a knowledge base by linking the project to a Confluence space
 - Create an issue in the Service Desk project with the summary "Cellphone order for work"
 - Observe that the Confluence article is found in the *Related KB panel section*, and also by the *KB search* when typing the issue summary
 !Step2.png|thumbnail!
 - Change the summary of the issue to "Cellphone order - work"

h3. Expected behavior
 - The Confluence page "How to order a cellphone for work" should be found in the *Related Knowledge Base panel*
 - When searching for "Cellphone order - work" in *Search knowledge base*, the page should also be found

h3. Observed behavior
 - The Confluence page "How to order a cellphone for work" is not found in the *Related Knowledge Base panel*
 - When searching for "Cellphone order - work" in *Search knowledge base*, no page is found

!Step3.png|thumbnail!
h3. Workaround
 - Remove the minus character "-" from the issue summary

h3. Notes
 * The issue is occurring because the minus character "-" is treated as a special character in the Confluence search, as explained in [Confluence Search Syntax|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/confluence-search-syntax-158720.html].
 * Basically, "-" means "except", so in the example above, Confluence is search for any page containing the words "Cellphone" or "Order" *except* for the word "work".
 * The example above is only mentioning the minus character, but there might other issues with other special characters or words such as AND, OR, "+", etc...
 * Therefore, the fix should consist in parsing the summary field in a way that these special characters/words are treating in a way that they are not impacting the KB article search.
 * This issue also seems to appear when using other characters like "ñ" and accented words like "á" and "é" although, interestingly, using the basic roman alphabet equivalents like "n" instead of "ñ" give the results from articles containing them.
fields.summary: The Related Knowledge Base search can't find relevant articles when special characters are in the issue summary

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When using the Service Desk Mail Handler, if the customer replies to a notification and includes an attachment with a filename shorter than 3 characters, the email is discarded and no comment is added to the ticket.

h3. Steps to reproduce

- Configure an SMTP server in ⚙ > System > Outgoing Mail
- Create a Service Desk project
- Configure a SD Mail Handler in Project Settings > Email Requests
- Log into the Customer Portal as a customer, and create a Request
- Log into the customer's mailbox and wait for the "Issue Created" Customer Notification to be received
- Reply to this customer notification and include a file that has less than 2 characters in the filename. For example: 0

h3. Expected behavior

A comment is added to the Service Desk ticket and the file is attached to it.

h3. Observed behavior

- The email is discarded by Service Desk and no comment is added to the ticket
- The customer does not receive any notification about this failure
- The following FAILURE is shown in the UI in the SD logs:
 !SD_Mail_Error.png|thumbnail! 

- The following exception is found in the incoming email logs:
{code}
2018-09-17 14:33:31,419 ERROR [] Caesium-1-2 anonymous     Exception when MailHandlerWorker handles message: 
java.lang.RuntimeException: Unexpected error while running action as user 'julienreyjiratestcustomer2@gmail.com'
	at com.atlassian.pocketknife.internal.util.runner.AuthenticationContextUtilImpl.runAs(AuthenticationContextUtilImpl.java:60) [?:?]
	at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.feature.emailchannel.IncomingEmailServiceImpl.inEmailContext(IncomingEmailServiceImpl.java:473) [?:?]
	at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.feature.emailchannel.IncomingEmailServiceImpl.lambda$doCreateNewOrCommentOnIssueWithMailChannel$15(IncomingEmailServiceImpl.java:172) [?:?]
	at io.atlassian.fugue.Either$Right.fold(Either.java:620) [fugue-4.5.0.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.feature.emailchannel.IncomingEmailServiceImpl.doCreateNewOrCommentOnIssueWithMailChannel(IncomingEmailServiceImpl.java:170) [?:?]
	at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.feature.emailchannel.IncomingEmailServiceImpl.lambda$createNewOrCommentOnIssueWithMailChannel$6(IncomingEmailServiceImpl.java:145) [?:?]
...
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Prefix string too short
	at java.io.File.createTempFile(File.java:2001) [?:1.8.0_121]
	at java.io.File.createTempFile(File.java:2070) [?:1.8.0_121]
	at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.comment.InternalServiceDeskCommentServiceScala.com$atlassian$servicedesk$internal$comment$InternalServiceDeskCommentServiceScala$$createTempFile(InternalServiceDeskCommentServiceScala.scala:521) [?:?]
	at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.comment.InternalServiceDeskCommentServiceScala$$anonfun$14.apply(InternalServiceDeskCommentServiceScala.scala:502) [?:?]
{code}

h3. Workaround

There is no ideal workaround for this issue besides ensuring that customers never attach files that have less than 3 characters when replying to notifications. This can be a problem when customers use mail clients which convert images into thumbnails, since these thumbnails often have names of only 1 character.

h3. Notes

This issuse *only occurs with the Service Desk Mail Handler*, and *only when replying to a notification* to comment in a ticket. It does not occur when creating an issue via email.

Also, this issue does not occur with the JIRA Core Mail Handler which is configured in ⚙ > System > Incoming Mail (the bug was fixed for this Mail Handler in [JRASERVER-1229|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-1229]).
fields.summary: The Service Mail Handler drops emails containing attachments with less than 3 characters

fields.description:
h3. Summary

A transition on comment triggered by an automation rule can take a long time to occur when a Service Desk issue is shared with an organization containing a high number of customers.
h3. Steps to reproduce

In a Service Desk project:
 - Create an automation rule that triggers a transition when a comment is added to a request
 - Create an organization with a high number of customers (for example 800)
 - Configure an outgoing mail server in ⚙ > System > Outgoing Mail
 - Make sure that customers notifications are enabled when a comment is added to a request
 - Create a Service Desk request and share it with the organization
 - Add a comment to the request

h3. Expected behavior

The request should transition immediately to the new status.
h3. Observed behavior

* The request takes a while to transition (20-30 seconds)
* (!) Depending on how big is the organization, a notification can be delayed up to 40 minutes

h3. Workaround

No good workaround at the moment, besides disabling the comment notifications, or reducing the number of customers in the organization.
h3. More details about the root cause of this issue

The issue is related to email notification handling.

Preconditions:
 1) Issue is shared with organization
 2) Comment notifications are enabled
 3) Outgoing email server is configured

When this is the case, we iterate over each member of the organization and check his status (which results in a couple of DB queries). When there are 800+ people in the organization we end up with ~3000-4000 queries just for a single comment, which will slow down the transition.
fields.summary: Slow transition triggered by an automation rule when an issue is shared with an organization

 -> Run SQL

List all KB space links:

select * from "AO_54307E_CONFLUENCEKB"

update "AO_54307E_CONFLUENCEKB" set "SPACE_URL" = 'https://instance.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/correctspace' where "ID" = xx
{code}

fields.description:
h3. Problem
* In some Jira views the "Due" timestamp shown when hovering over an SLA field is displayed using the *System Default* timezone rather than the *Current User* timezone. This causes doubt that the hours/minutes shown for an SLA field value are correct.
* This occurs in Search Results as well as Issue Filter gadgets in Jira Dashboards.

h3. Environment
* Initially observed  in Jira 7.6.7, Jira Service Desk 3.9.7

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an SLA
# View an issue subject to the SLA. Hover over the SLA field and note the Due timestamp.
# Search for the issue using "key = ISSUEKEY". Include the SLA field in the search results columns. However over the SLA field and note the Due timestamp. Save the filter.
# Create a Dashboard. Add an Issue Filter gadget using the saved filter from prior step and include the SLA field. However over the SLA field and note the Due timestamp. Save the filter.

h3. Expected Results
* The Due timestamp should match in all views of the issue.
* The Due timestamp should be displayed using the current user's timezone.

h3. Actual Results
* The Due timestamp is shown in the current user's timezone on Issue Details.
!sla-timezone-issuedetails.png|thumbnail! 
* The Due timestamp is shown in the system default timezone on Search Results and in Issue Filter gadgets.
!sla-timezone-searchresults.png|thumbnail! !sla-timezone-jiradashboard.png|thumbnail!

h3. Workaround
None is known.
fields.summary: SLA Due Date timezone is incorrect in Jira Dashboard views

fields.description:
*Description of Problem*

A request type can be configured to have fields that are hidden and those fields can be given default values. 

The default value that is defined may become invalid if the configuration of the field is changed. 
* Example: Multi select field, default value is set. At a later date the multi select field is changed to no longer have that value as a selection. 
** The request type remains configured to use the original default value which is now invalid

*Suggested Change*

JSD should alert the admin of the invalid default value so that it may immediately be corrected. The invalid default value will cause errors when creating tickets. 
* In the case of issue security the invalid value may cause issues to be created with an invalid security level
* The alert could be similar to what is shown when there is a problem with permissions.
fields.summary: Alert admin when request type is configured with invalid default value

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
----
h3. Summary

Service Desk 3.2 introduces a new [Approvals feature|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver072/configuring-jira-service-desk-approvals-832185058.html]. However, the approvers can only approve the ticket via the UI
h3. Suggestion

Make it possible for Approvers to _truly_ approve/decline requests via email

The prior ticket that resolved this request still requires access to the Service Desk server. A true email-based approval would be driven by the reply to the email itself. All the previous resolution did was add convenient "Approve" and "Deny" shortcuts to the portal, but they still required you to use the portal.

If an Approver is out of the office and the Service Desk is not accessible when not on the corporate network (I assume a fairly common scenario), you cannot Approve/Deny using the email that gets sent. Often, our Approvers just reply "Approved" to the message, thinking this is sufficient, but it just adds a comment of Approved, and does not log their Approval and transition the ticket.

A true email-based approval could use an automation to parse a carefully crafted mailto: link inserted in the Approval emails that get sent and thus rely only on the email to log approvals.
fields.summary: Allow approvals to truly work via email

fields.description:
h4. Summary
When enabling Service Desk for a normal project, there will be an error viewing the issue if that particular issue has a comment made by *Anonymous* users.

Additionally, anonymous comments generated by post-functions or added by the JIRA Service Desk mail handler causes the "activity" section to look empty (insert screenshot from this ticket) and in some cases, an error (see attachment) message.

The error displayed is 
{panel}
Error rendering 'com.atlassian.jira.jira-view-issue-plugin:activitymodule'
{panel}

h5. Diagnostics
Run the following SQL query to check if there are any issues with author set to NULL:
{code}
select * from jiraaction where author=NULL
{code}
(you may need to try 'where author is NULL' depending on the database implementation)

If there are any records returned - your JIRA is affected by this

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Create a normal project
# Give *Group (Anyone)* permission to browse project and comment on issue
# Create an issue in the project
# Have an anonymous user (not logged in) comment on that issue
# Enable Service Desk for the project
# View that particular issue in the Issue Navigator

OR

# On Service Desk project, create a comment on some issue ticket
# Reset comment author through database on that isuse:
{code}update jiraaction set author=NULL where id = xxxxx;{code}
# Refresh issue ticket in browser

OR
This issue can also occur when JIRA is connected to a shared mailbox and retrieves a message when the same message is coincidentally deleted from the mailbox by another mail client (manually Error rendering 'com.atlassian.jira.jira-view-issue-plugin:activitymodule'or via another application, i.e. outside of Original JIRA)

h4. Expected Results
# Everything works normally
# Able to view the issue without any errors

h4. Actual Results
# When viewing the issue in the Issue Navigator, there will be the following error:
 !1.png|thumbnail! 
or the Activity tab will be blank:
 !Bildschirmfoto 2018-08-15 um 13.27.40.png|thumbnail! 

h5. Workaround (if upgrade to the version where the issue is fixed is not possible)

1) Stop JIRA
2) Run the following SQL queries:
{code}
delete from jiraaction where author=NULL and id = xxxxx; (try is NULL if it doesn't work)
{code}

where xxxxx is the issue ID as identified by the Diagnostic SQL query aobve

3) Start JIRA and verify the issue is fixed

If running Oracle, don't forget to run COMMIT statement after the 'delete' as otherwise the changes will not be written to the table.
fields.summary: An error or empty content displays in the activity tab of issues fter switching project to Service Desk type due to comments from anonymous users

fields.description:
h5. Problem
With the *jira.permission.comment.user=denied* property set, new issues can be created for non-customers.

h5. Steps to reproduce
# Add the workflow property key pair below for Closed issues.
 !property.png|thumbnail! 
# Set {{Administration > Applications > Email requests > Public email comments}} to _Yes, allow non-customers and external people to comment on a request via email_.
# Create a Service Desk issue for a customer and trigger a customer notification to be sent to the customer.
# Close the issue.
# Remove the customer from the project's customer list and ensure that the project's Customer Permission is *not set to* allow anyone to raise requests.
# As the customer, reply to the customer notification.

h5. Expected result
The reply will not be processed at all.

h5. Actual result
The reply is processed and created as a new request despite the user no longer has access to the project.

h5. Note
Without the *jira.permission.comment.user=denied* property set, replies from the user will just be processed and added as comments to the existing ticket with label {{NO ACCESS TO REQUEST}} on each comment.
fields.summary: New issue is created for non-customers if jira.permission.comment.user=denied is set

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When the SLA manager checks if there has been a change due to a config, it checks and acts only on start, if it cant find a "new" start, it cleans up all existing events, (start, stop etc) thats the reason that when it then comes to rendering SLAs for an issue, there is nothing to be found, and therefore the SLA is no longer "applicable" for the issue.
h3. Expected Results
 * All SLAs that apply to an issue are shown in the correct state

h3. Actual Results
 * Not all SLAs will be shown for an issue

h3. Workaround

[Repair the SLA using the reconstruct REST Endpoint|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/missing-corrupted-sla-data-in-jira-service-desk-828790603.html]
fields.summary: Making changes to an SLA doesn't necessarily check all events, only the start
